title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Always the right choice?
No! In some cases untidy data can be preferred!

Often for performance/memory reasons
We’ll cover this when we get to spatial data

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Variable types
A defining characteristic of a variable is its type

nations['population'].dtype

dtype('int64')



This should be familar to computer scientists!

The type of a variable determines what kinds of values it can take and how we should interpret them

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Variable types



Nominal

Categorical
Arbitrary

Ordinal
Quantitative

Interval
Ratio




Nominal variables
An unordered set of non-numeric values, representing labels or categories

Categorical - Finite
Possible values are finite and known

Colors: {red, green, blue}
Regions: {South Asia, Europe & Central Asia, …}



Arbitrary - Infinite
Possible values are unbounded

Addresses: {“12 Main St. Boston MA”, “45 Wall St. New York NY”, …}
Names: {“John Smith”, “Jane Doe”, …}

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Variable types



Nominal

Categorical
Arbitrary

Ordinal
Quantitative

Interval
Ratio




Ordinal variables
An ordered set of (usually) non-numeric values, representing levels

Grades: {A, B, C, D, F}
Ratings: {G, PG, PG-13, R}

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Variable types



Nominal

Categorical
Arbitrary

Ordinal
Quantitative

Interval
Ratio




Quantitative variables
Numeric data that we can perform mathematical operations on

Interval
Location of 0 is arbitrary, only differences/intervals can be compared

Date-Times: Jan, 19, 2006



Ratio
0 is well-defined and meaningful. Can compare values as ratios

Height: {5’3”, 6’1”, 5’9”,…}
Population: 23M, 350k, 1.4B, …

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Operations by type


Nominal (Labels or categories)

Concrete types: str, bool, category
Operations: =, ≠



Ordinal (Ordered, non-numeric)

Concrete types: str, int, category
Operations: =, ≠, <, >



Interval (Arbitrary 0)

Concrete types: float, int, datetime
Operations: =, ≠, <, >, -



Ratio (Well-defined 0)

Concrete types: float, int, timedelta
Operations: =, ≠, <, >, -, /

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Schema
The schema of a data frame is the specification of the set of variables and the type of each variable

In Pandas we can access this with df.info


nations.info()

<class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>
RangeIndex: 180 entries, 0 to 179
Data columns (total 5 columns):
 #   Column          Non-Null Count  Dtype  
---  ------          --------------  -----  
 0   name            180 non-null    object 
 1   region          180 non-null    object 
 2   income          180 non-null    float64
 3   population      180 non-null    int64  
 4   lifeExpectancy  180 non-null    float64
dtypes: float64(2), int64(1), object(2)
memory usage: 7.2+ KB

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Nominal types
If we want a nominal value to be categorical or ordinal, we can tell Pandas explicitly

nations['region'] = nations['region'].astype('category')
nations.info()

Data columns (total 5 columns):

---  ------          --------------  -----

 2   income          180 non-null    float64 
 3   population      180 non-null    float64 
 4   lifeExpectancy  180 non-null    float64 
dtypes: category(1), float64(3), object(1)
memory usage: 6.1+ KB

                  'Sub-Saharan Africa'],
, ordered=False, categories_dtype=object)

Index
The index of a DataFrame in Pandas is a special column used to identify each row.

Mostly exists for performance reasons. Any column could be used as an index.

By default the index is a new column that identifies each row with an integer

Missing data
Sometimes a value doesn’t exist!

What if we don’t know the life expectency for a country?

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Missing data
Pandas uses special values to denote missingness:

np.NaN (Not a number) for general numeric types and categorical types
NaT (Not a time) for datetime types
None or pd.NA for other types

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Ggplot
ggplot is a hugely influential visualizatation library.

Designed by Hadley Wickham
Only for the R language

Let’s Plot is a port for Python (and Kotlin)

We’ll be using it in class

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
CSV (and TSV) files
“Simplest” and most common data file format.

Plain text file
Each line is a row
Each column is separated by a delimiter: “,” for CSV, tab for TSV.
First row (usually) specifies column labels

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Loading CSV (and TSV) files
Files can be loaded into Pandas with pd.read_csv()

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
CSV (and TSV) issues
No explicit schema! We need to guess the type of each column

Pandas usally does a good job, but could get it wrong!

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
CSV (and TSV) issues
Ambiguity! What if a value contains a comma?

Usually handled by quoting text
Leads to its own issues

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
CSV (and TSV) issues
Lack of standardization! Many different ways of handling different data types

Leads to this:

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Python
We can load a DataFrame from Python structures a s well

Column format
Records format

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
JSON (JavaScript Object Notation)
JSON is a plain text format that describes nested list and dict structures (array and object in JavaScript)

Pandas can read and write JSON using the columns or records format

text:
The set of possible encodings depends on the variable type
Categorical variables have a different space of possibilities

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Choose a geometry
How do we represent each observation?



            
            
            


   
   


Here we are representing each observation with a distinct point in 2-d space (a scatterplot).

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text: Many different geometries

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Geometries are abstract
The same geometry might be rendered in different ways

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Geometries are abstract
Diffent geometries may have different requirements (and options) for aesthetics:


Point: x and y coordinates
Line: x and y coordinates, order
Bar: x or y coordinate, length

Text: x and y coordinates, text
Interval: x coordinate, min, max
Boxplot: Median, quantiles

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
section: Define a scale for each mapping
text:
Define a scale for each mapping
A scale determines how we translate the domain of a variable to the range of a visual dimension

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Scales are (usually) invertable functions
Most commonly a linear function





But can be non-linear, e.g. logarithmic

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
section: Show scales through axes and legends
text:
Show scales through axes and legends
Axes show the scale for each position dimension.
Legends show the scale for other dimensions (color, shape, size, etc.)

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
(Optional) Define a coordinate system
A coordinate system defines how the range of each scale is represented. Usually Cartesian coordinate system, but others are possible, such as polar

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
section: A layer is a single view of the data
text:
A layer is a single view of the data
Encompasses data + mapping + geometry. A plot may have more than one layer to show multiple properties of a dataset or multiple datasets.

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text: Scales are (generally) shared across layers

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Finally: add annotations
Annotations, such as titles captions and highlights, give additional context and information to the viewer.

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Creating a plot
The ggplot() function will create an empty plot object.

ggplot()

   
   



Here we get an error as we haven’t defined our components!

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Adding a layer
We can add a layer to our plot, specifying the data, mapping and geometry. Here we’ll add a layer with a point geometry.



ggplot() + geom_point(data=nations, 
  mapping=aes(x='income', y='lifeExpectancy')
)

   
   



aes() defines an aesthetic mapping, using the column names of our dataframe.
geom_point() creates a point geometry layer.

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Equivalent syntax
If we want default data and mappings to share across layers we can pass them to the ggplot() function.



ggplot(
  data=nations, 
  mapping=aes(x='income', y='lifeExpectancy')
) + geom_point() + geom_line()

   
   



Here we’ll add both point and line geometries

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Choosing scales
We didn’t need to specify scales, Let’s plot has sensible defaults.



ggplot() + geom_point(data=nations, 
  mapping=aes(x='income', y='lifeExpectancy')
) + scale_x_continuous(trans='log2')

   
   



we can change the scales by adding them to our specification.
Here we’ll set the x axis scale to be logarithmic

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Changing the coordinate system
We can similarly change the default (Cartesean) coordinate system.



ggplot() + geom_point(data=nations, 
  mapping=aes(x='income', y='lifeExpectancy')
) + coord_polar(theta='y') + scale_x_continuous(trans='log2')

   
   



Here we’ll make a polar plot

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Adding annotations
We can also add annotations, such as a plot title. ggtitle() will add a title to our plot.



ggplot() + geom_point(data=nations, 
  mapping=aes(x='income', y='lifeExpectancy')
) +  ggtitle('Income vs. Life Exp.')

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Configuration
Outside of our grammar, we can configure the rendering of our plot.



ggplot() + geom_point(data=nations, 
  mapping=aes(x='income', y='lifeExpectancy')
) +  ggsize(400, 400)

   
   



ggsize() lets us set the size of the output.
theme lets us adjust many other aesthetic properties.

Most effective representation may depend on the type of data

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Some scales are complicated!
Color is especially tricky.

Humans percieve color non-linearly
Not all humans percieve the same set of colors
One color can encode multiple channels

We’ll cover this in a later lecture!

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
A first principle: importance ordering
“Encode more important information more effectively”

A visualization is more effective than another visualization if the information conveyed by one visualization is more readily perceived than the information in the other visualization.

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Another principle: expressiveness
“A set of facts is expressible in a [visual] language if it contains a sentence [visualization] that:”

“Encodes all the facts in the set”
“Encodes only the facts in the set”

What does this mean?

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
A (hopefully obvious) principle: consistency
The properties of the image (visual variables) should match the properties of the data

Don’t encode a length variable with color or a position variable with size

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Express all the facts: overplotting
Overlapping points can make it impossible to tell the number of observations

How many total cars are represented?

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Encode only the facts: consistency
The properties of the image (visual variables) should match the properties of the data

Nations are not ordinal!

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Encode only the facts: ordering
Visual orderings convey meaning, even when there is none!

“Because we are almost never interested in seeing Alabama first, it is astonishing how often data displays use alphabetical order as the organizing principle of choice” - Howard Wainer

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Tufte’s philosophy: minimalism
Five principles

Above all else show the data
Maximize the data-ink ratio
Erase non-data-ink
Erase redundant data-ink
Revise and edit

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
CSV (and TSV) files
“Simplest” and most common data file format.

Plain text file
Each line is a row
Each column is separated by a delimiter: “,” for CSV, tab for TSV.
First row (usually) specifies column labels

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Loading CSV (and TSV) files
Files can be loaded into Pandas with pd.read_csv()

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
CSV (and TSV) issues
No explicit schema! We need to guess the type of each column

Pandas usally does a good job, but could get it wrong!

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
CSV (and TSV) issues
Ambiguity! What if a value contains a comma?

Usually handled by quoting text
Leads to its own issues

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
CSV (and TSV) issues
Lack of standardization! Many different ways of handling different data types

Leads to this:

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Python
We can load a DataFrame from Python structures a s well

Column format
Records format

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
JSON (JavaScript Object Notation)
JSON is a plain text format that describes nested list and dict structures (array and object in JavaScript)

Pandas can read and write JSON using the columns or records format

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Space of visualizations














Large number of possible visualizations for any given dataset:
\[\text{variables} \times \text{aesthetics} \times \text{geoms} \times \text{scales}...\]

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
section: Automating the Design of Graphical Presentations of Relational Information
text:
Automating the Design of Graphical Presentations of Relational Information


Can we automate the process of creating good visualizations?

How can we efficiently search the space of possible visualizations
What criteria do we use?







Jock MacKinlay

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
MacKinlay’s Criteria
“Expressiveness criteria identify graphical languages that express the desired information.”
“Effectiveness criteria identify which of these graphical languages, in a given situation, is the most effective at exploiting the capabilities of the output medium and the human visual system.”

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
section: Can we automate the process of creating good visualizations?
text:
Can we automate the process of creating good visualizations?


To answer this question we first need to determine:

How can we efficiently search the space of possible visualizations?
What criteria do we use?

In the 1980s Jock MacKinlay was one of the first to tackle these questions.

text: Addressing data skew and outliers

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Clipping
Clipping removes outliers (but loses information!)



ggplot() + geom_point(
  data=s_asia, 
  mapping=aes(color='name', 
  x='population', y='income'), 
size=5)

   
   




ggplot() + geom_point(
  data=s_asia[s_asia['population'] < 1e9], 
  mapping=aes(color='name', 
  x='population', y='income'), 
  size=5)

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Axis breaks
Axis breaks are another common solution







But they can violate consistency!






A well-implemented break can be clear.

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Log scales
Log scales can address outliers, but also overall data skew.



ggplot() + geom_point(
  data=nations, 
  mapping=aes(
    x='income', y='lifeExpectancy')
  ) + scale_x_continuous()\
  + ggsize(400,400)

   
   


Skewed data, makes it hard to distinguish the majority of observations.


ggplot() + geom_point(
  data=nations, 
  mapping=aes(
    x='income', y='lifeExpectancy')
  ) + scale_x_continuous(trans='log10')\
  + ggsize(400,400)

   
   


A log-scale spreads out observations across orders of magnitude.

Different geometries are interpreted differently.

Bar charts encode ratios
Pie charts encode proportions of a whole
Line charts encode trends

Area (or even arc-length) are more relevant to perception.






Thus donut charts can be just as effective!

\[\text{position} = \frac{\text{value} - \min}{\max - \min} \cdot \text{visual range}\]

text:
Should axes start at 0? - consistency
Bar charts imply ratio variables. So 0 is important!

ggplot() + geom_bar(
  data=cars, mapping=aes(y='Name', x='Weight_in_lbs'), stat='identity') \
+ scale_x_continuous(limits=[3000, 4500]) + scale_y_discrete(lablim=20)

   
   


A Chevelle is not 10x the weight of a Citroen DS!

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Should axes start at 0? - consistency
Point geoms can highlight a relvant range without violating consistency.



ggplot() + geom_bar(
  data=cars.sort_values('Weight_in_lbs'), 
  mapping=aes(y='Name', x='Weight_in_lbs'), 
  stat='identity') \
+ ggsize(600, 400) + scale_y_discrete(lablim=20)

   
   


Compare ratios

  mapping=aes(y='Name', x='Weight_in_lbs'),

Compare position

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Axis breaks
In general breaks are not recommended; much more cognitive work for the reader!







Log scales show all the data directly.






Breaks require separate parsing of two (or more) sections.

Not implemented in (base) ggplot!

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Log scales
Consider log-scales when:



Data has significant outliers that dominate an axis.
Data spans several orders of magnitude.
Want to emphasize percentage changes.



ggplot() + geom_point(
  data=nations, 
  mapping=aes(
    x='income', y='lifeExpectancy')
  ) + scale_x_continuous(trans='log10')\
  + ggsize(400,400)

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Log scales
Consider log-scales when:



Data has significant outliers that dominate an axis.
Data spans several orders of magnitude.
Want to emphasize percentage changes.

Remember that logs turn multiplications into additions.
\[\log(xy) = log(x) + log(y)\]
Equal steps on log axis correspond to equal multiplicative changes.


ggplot() + geom_point(
  data=nations, 
  mapping=aes(
    x='income', y='lifeExpectancy')
  ) + scale_x_continuous(trans='log10')\
  + ggsize(400,400)

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text:
Log scales

On the log scale, a slope of 1 corresponds to exponential growth.

title: Data Analytics and Visualization
text: What did we find?
